--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Cakalic" <james.p.cakalic@m...> wrote:
> Hmm. Sounds like you have your "Designer" hat on. That wasn't what I
> understood to be the context of the question. "How do I test a private
> method" is a question someone wearing their "Tester" hat would ask.
> Given that context, my mind hasn't changed. If the private method is
> already tested through an existing public method then you don't need
> to do anything. In fact, exposing the method and writing an explicit
> test against it is duplication.

Is it really?

First: the question "How do I test this private method" is a trigger
to me to swap out to my Designer hat - it means that there's an
abstraction that's worth taking out.

Second: if it's already tested _enough_, then there is no need to test
it, is there? But I don't know why I would ask that question if it's
already tested enough.

Thirdly: if it's not tested enough, then exposing the method and
writing new tests is not duplication - in fact, it can significantly
reduce duplication by removing the need to duplicate extraneous setup
work.

Robert.
